title: Five-year-old helps mum win keys at Bentleigh auction
text:
A five-year-old’s fear of missing out spurred a $500 winning bid in a Bentleigh auction that shot $51,000 past expectations.

And a market expert watching the sale reckons the kid had the right idea.

Four bidders pursued 1/14 Blair St, with the keys eventually going to a woman whose final bid was cast at the urging of her daughter.

National Property Buyers director and buyer’s advocate Antony Bucello said with just seven significant auction weekends until Christmas, the child had the right idea.

“I think the five-year-old’s mother will be thanking her for pushing her in the not too distant future; they may well have found themselves needing another $10,000 for the same property in the next few weeks,” Mr Bucello said.

“There’s a sense, not necessarily of panic, but that people are stretching themselves to get in and realising that there aren’t a lot of options for them.”

Woodards Bentleigh’s Ben Quigley said the three-bedroom townhouse was on the market at $1.18 million and sold for $1.231 million, with the last two bidders fighting it out in $500 increments.

“The young girl was pushing her mum along, not wanting to see her beaten, saying ‘come on’,” Mr Quigley said.

Bidders had come from far and wide, including Doncaster and Wantirna South, attracted by McKinnon Secondary College zoning.

CoreLogic records show 912 homes went to auction last week, with preliminary results showing 75 per cent of them sold under the hammer.

With many auctions attracting multiple buyers, and helping to drive the clearance rate, the number of underbidders was building up across the city and should carry the market through one of the busiest auction weekends of the year this weekend, Mr Bucello said.

“I didn’t expect it to turn this quickly … but until we get some more stock, I can’t see it changing in the near future,” he said.

More than 1000 homes are tipped to go under the hammer this week as sellers try to get in ahead of the Melbourne Cup long weekend, when auction numbers traditionally drop off.

December 14 is expected to be the last significant auction weekend for the year.
description: It would have been back to the drawing board for a weekend buyer if it wasn’t for her young daughter, who helped mum win their new home and also got the nod from a market expert.
